['Shrimp - Small, pink-hued crustacean commonly used in cooking and eaten as seafood.', 'Lobster - Large marine crustaceans with a hard exoskeleton, known for their delicious meat.', 'Crab - A large family of crustaceans characterized by lateral appendages on the first segment of their body.', 'Oyster - Mollusks that live in saltwater and have a rough, irregularly-shaped shell.', 'Clam - Bivalve mollusk with two hinged shells often found in sandy or muddy areas.', 'Mussel - Filter-feeding bivalve mollusks known for their elongated and compressed shape.', 'Scallop - Round, flat bivalves that have a distinctive fan-shaped shell.', 'Barnacle - Marine crustaceans attached to hard surfaces like rocks or ship hulls by a cement-like substance.', 'Cockle - Small edible saltwater clams with two valves, typically found in sandy beaches and estuaries.', 'Ostracode (ostrich) - Marine bivalve mollusks known for their elongated shells resembling the back of an ostrich.', 'Bivalve - A class of marine and freshwater mollusks that have a two-part hinged shell, including mussels and clams.', 'Cephalopod (octopus) - An invertebrate animal with a large head, bilateral body symmetry, and tentacles, although not traditionally considered "shellfish."', 'Cuttlebone - The internal calcified shell of the cuttlefish used as a dietary supplement for birds.', 'Horseshoe crab (Limulus polyphemus) - An ancient marine arthropod, not true crustacean or mollusk but often categorized under "shellfish" due to its hard exoskeleton.', 'Krill - Small planktonic crustaceans that form a crucial part of the aquatic food chain and are consumed by many marine animals, including baleen whales.', 'Murex (sea snail) - A genus of predatory sea snails known for producing red pigment called "murexide" used as a dye in ancient times.', 'Mytilus (blue mussel) - A type of bivalve mollusk commonly found along rocky shorelines, and often cultivated for food.', 'Periwinkle (Littorina littorea) - Small sea snail with a round shell used in culinary purposes as an edible delicacy.', 'Artemia (sea monkeys) - Free-swimming crustaceans often kept as pets but not typically considered traditional "shellfish."', 'Foraminifera (forams) - Single-celled protists with a shell made of calcium carbonate, found in both marine and freshwater environments']

['Tailgating - driving too closely behind another vehicle, often leading to rear-end collisions.', 'Crash - an accident involving two or more vehicles, typically resulting in damage and injury.', "Slamming - forcefully hitting the brakes causing a vehicle's rear end to slam into whatever is directly in front of it.", 'Collision - a direct impact between two objects or vehicles.', 'Rear-end accident - an incident where one car crashes into the back of another.', 'Impact zone - the area affected by the collision, often showing damage to both vehicles involved.', 'Spinout - when a vehicle loses traction and begins to spin out of control, potentially leading to a rear-end collision with other cars or objects on the road.', 'Pile-up - a multiple car crash involving several rear-end collisions in quick succession.', 'Backing up accident - an incident when a vehicle moving backward hits another object or vehicle from behind.', 'Reaction time - the time taken by a driver to respond and brake after noticing a potential collision, affecting the likelihood of a rear-end crash.', 'Blind spot - an area in a car where a driver cannot see other vehicles or objects while looking forward or through peripheral mirrors.', 'Traffic congestion - heavy traffic conditions that can increase the risk of rear-end collisions due to limited maneuverability and abrupt stops.', 'Braking distance - the distance a vehicle travels from the moment brakes are applied until it comes to a complete stop, which is crucial in avoiding or minimizing the severity of a rear-end collision.', 'Follow too closely - when one driver is driving at an unsafe distance behind another car, increasing the chances of a rear-end crash.', 'Rear bumper damage - visible damage to the rear end and bumper area of vehicles involved in collisions.', 'Impact force - the energy generated during a collision, which can cause injury to passengers and structural damage to cars.', 'Vehicle deceleration - the process by which a moving vehicle reduces its speed due to braking or other factors, affecting the likelihood of rear-end collisions.', 'Tire skid marks - tire impressions left on the road surface that can indicate sudden acceleration or hard braking leading up to a collision.', 'Accident reconstruction - a scientific process used by investigators to determine how and why a collision occurred, often involving analysis of rear-end collisions.', 'Fender bender - a minor fender-to-fender accident typically involving low speeds and little damage or injury to the vehicles and occupants involved.']

['Nucleus - The central and most important part of an object, movement, or group, forming the core.', 'Atom - An extremely small particle that forms the basic unit of matter, with a nucleus at its center.', 'Heart - Both figuratively and literally refers to the core organ responsible for pumping blood throughout the body.', "Epicenter - The point on Earth's surface directly above where an earthquake or other seismic event originates from the core.", 'Core - A central region of something, often used in reference to a planetary body or organization.', 'Kernel - In computer science, it refers to the core component of a program that can run independently and perform basic tasks.', "Earth's core - The innermost layer of our planet made up primarily of iron and nickel.", 'Core muscle - Refers to several groups of muscles found in the human torso, crucial for stability and posture.', 'Atomic nucleus - The small, dense region at the center of an atom that contains protons and neutrons.', "Hull core - A term used in maritime shipping, referring to the central structure or part of a ship's hull.", 'Core principle - An essential idea or belief around which something is based or built.', 'Nuclear core - The center portion of a nuclear reactor where fission takes place.', 'Central cortex - Refers to the core part of the cerebral cortex in the brain.', 'Core stability - A concept often associated with physical fitness, referring to the ability to maintain balance and posture through engagement of muscle groups around a central area.', 'Pith - The innermost layer of plant stems or roots, which is often considered its core.', 'Centerpiece - An object placed at the center of something for decorative effect, representing its core feature.', 'Core memory - A type of computer memory technology that was prevalent in early computing systems and served as a crucial component.', "Lava core - The innermost part of a volcano' mantle from which lava is expelled during eruptions.", 'Heartland - An area or region considered the central part of something, often with cultural or political significance.', 'Core concept - A fundamental idea or thought that underpins an argument, theory, or field of study.']

CLUE: Northern black and white diving birds
OUTPUT: ['Puffin', 'Guillemot', 'Razorbill', 'Atlantic Puffel (also known as Aythya marila)', 'Black-legged Kittiwake (Rissa tridactyla)', "Leach's Storm-Petrel (Oceanodroma leucophryna)", 'Northern Fulmar (Fulmarus glacialis)', 'Common Murre (Uria aalge)', 'Tufted Puffin (Calonectris diomedea)', "Leach's Petrel (Pterodroma leucoptera)", 'Black-backed Gull (Larus fuscus) - Although not a diving bird, it often associated with Arctic and subarctic environments where other puffins can be found.', 'Great Skua (Stercorarius skua) - Mainly known as a seabird predator but also frequents the same habitats as some of the others on this list.', 'Kelp Gull (Larus dominicanus) - Another gull species that inhabits similar northern regions and dives for food, though not strictly black and white in plumage.', 'White-winged Diver (Phalacrocorax lucidus) - A diver with distinctive coloring resembling the description.', 'Northern Shag (Gulosus arctirostris) - Mainly found around coastlines, this bird fits the description as it dives for food and is black-and-white in appearance.', 'Crested Tern (Thalasseus bergii) - Although primarily white with a black cap, they inhabit northern regions where some other listed species can be found.', 'Black Guillemot (Guillemote noir) - A variant of the European Guillemot that is mostly black and white.', 'Long-tailed Jaeger (Stercorarius longicaudus) - Although not strictly a diver, this bird frequents northern waters where some diving species live.', 'Northern Gannet (Morus bassanus) - Mainly known as an oceanic predator but has strong ties to the same environments and habitats of these diving birds.', 'Black-throated Diver (Gavia arctica) - A true diver that is black and white, fitting the description well.']

['Beads - Small decorative objects strung on a thread to form jewelry or ornaments.', 'Links - Individual components connected in a series, forming a continuous sequence.', 'Chainmail - Armor made of interlocked metal rings, typically used in medieval times.', 'Carabiners - Metal loops with spring-loaded gates used to connect things together quickly and securely (often seen in climbing or camping).', 'Gears - Rotating machine parts with teeth that mesh to transmit torque when assembled together.', 'Chains - Series of connected metal rings, commonly used for security or as a means of transportation.', 'Stitches - A single looped or straight seam created by passing the needle through fabric in sewing or knitting.', 'Ties - Connections made to bind things together securely; can also refer to ropes, cords, or chains used for binding.', 'Ropes - Cords constructed from twisted or braided strands of fiber (like cotton, hemp, nylon) and often used in lifting or pulling tasks.', 'Bows - Curved structures that connect two objects together; often attached by a looped chain.', 'Hinges - Mechanical devices that allow for the swinging motion between two objects (like doors and frames).', 'Lifelines - Safety devices used in climbing to prevent falls; typically comprised of rope or webbing connected with a carabiner.', 'Bolts - Long, slender metal fasteners with threaded ends that are inserted into pre-made holes and secured using nuts or washers.', 'Sequins - Small, reflective discs sewn onto fabric to create decorative patterns or designs when linked together in a chain arrangement.', 'Fiber optic cables - Bundles of glass fibers that transmit data by light signals; used for high-speed communication networks and internet connections.', 'Puzzle pieces - Individual components designed to fit with other pieces to complete an image or pattern when linked together in a chain configuration.']

["Nitrogen (N) - A colorless, odorless, and tasteless gas that makes up around 78% of Earth's atmosphere.", 'Nitrate - A polyatomic ion with the formula NO3-, commonly found in fertilizers and explosives.', 'Nitrogen fixation - The process by which atmospheric nitrogen (N2) is converted into ammonia (NH3), a form usable by plants.', 'Nitric oxide (NO) - A colorless gas with a pungent odor, produced during combustion processes and as a signaling molecule in the body.', 'Denitrification - The biological process of converting nitrate into nitrogen gas or nitrous oxide by certain bacteria.', 'Nitrogenase - An enzyme complex that catalyzes the reduction of atmospheric nitrogen (N2) to ammonia in some species of bacteria and archaea.', 'Ammonium (NH4+) - A positively charged polyatomic ion composed of one nitrogen atom bonded with four hydrogen atoms, commonly found in fertilizers.', 'Nitrous oxide (N2O) - Also known as laughing gas, it is a colorless and non-flammable gas used for anesthesia purposes but also contributes to ozone depletion.', 'Nitrite (NO2-) - A polyatomic ion consisting of one nitrogen atom bonded with two oxygen atoms, commonly found in food preservation processes as a disinfectant and antiomunitive agent.', 'Nitrous acid (HNO2) - A weak acid formed by the reaction between nitric oxide (NO) or nitric acid (HNO3) with water.', 'Ammonium hydroxide (NH4OH) - Also known as ammonia solution, it is a colorless liquid consisting of ammonia dissolved in water and commonly used for cleaning purposes.', 'Nitro group (-NO2) - A functional group consisting of one nitrogen atom bonded to two oxygen atoms, often found in organic compounds such as explosives or pesticides.', 'Aniline (C6H5NH2) - An aromatic amine that is commonly used in the production of dyes and pharmaceuticals.', 'Nitrocellulose (NC) - A highly flammable compound formed by nitration of cellulose, commonly used as a lacquer or explosive material.', 'Ammonium nitrate (NH4NO3) - An inorganic salt and the most widely used nitrogen fertilizer that can also be utilized as an oxidizing agent in explosives.', 'Nitrosamines (R2N-N=O) - A class of organic compounds with a common functional group consisting of one nitrogen atom bonded to two oxygen atoms and an amine, often found in food or cigarette smoke.', 'Nitrification - The biological oxidation of ammonia into nitrate by certain bacteria as part of the nitrogen cycle.', 'Azotobacter (Bacteria) - A genus of free-living, nitrogen-fixing bacteria that can convert atmospheric nitrogen gas into ammonia in soil.', 'Nitrosyl chloride (NOCl) - An unstable yellowish gas with an irritating odor formed by the reaction between nitric oxide and chlorine, often used as a catalyst or reagent in chemical synthesis.', 'Methemoglobinemia - A medical condition caused by elevated levels of methemoglobin (an altered form of hemoglobin) in the blood, which can be induced by exposure to nitrites and nitrates found in contaminated food or water sources.']
